metadata.title: Nano-sized g-C3N4 thin layer @ CeO2 sphere core-shell photocatalyst combined with H2O2 to degrade doxycycline in water under visible light irradiation

sections.text:
Contents lists available at ScienceDirect
Separation and Purification Technology
journal homepage: www.elsevier.com/locate/seppur
Nano-sized g-C3N4 thin layer @ CeO2 sphere core-shell photocatalyst combined with H2O2 to degrade doxycycline in water under visible light irradiation
Wei Liua,b, Jiabin Zhoua,b,⁎, Zeshu Hua
a School of Resources and Environmental Engineering, Wuhan University of Technology, Wuhan 430070, China b School of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering, Southwest Petroleum University, Chengdu 610500, China
A R T I C L E I N F O
Keywords: g-C3N4 thin layer @ CeO2 core-shell structure Hydrogen peroxide Doxycycline hydrochloride Photocatalytic degradation Visible light
A B S T R A C T
In this work, g-C3N4 thin layer @ CeO2 core-shell composite photocatalyst was synthesized by simple hydrothermal and in situ synthesis method for the first time, and it was combined with hydrogen peroxide (H2O2) to degrade the antibiotic doxycycline hydrochloride (DOX) under visible light. A series of techniques were employed to characterize the as-synthesized materials. XRD patterns indicated that the samples were successfully synthesized. SEM and TEM images displayed the core-shell microstructure of the as-synthesized composite. The surface element composition and the valence states of the samples were characterized by XPS. The optical properties of the materials were determined by DRS and FTIR. The results of FTIR and XPS indicated that strong interactions between g-C3N4 and CeO2 had formed during the synthesis process. Photodegradation experiments showed that the addition of H2O2 can greatly enhance the photocatalytic degradation rate of DOX. Active species trapping experiments and ESR experiments demonstrated that superoxide radicals, hydroxyl radicals and holes (%O2−, %OH and h+) played major roles in the photocatalytic process. Finally, a possible degradation mechanism was proposed. This work has synthesized a new core-shell structure system for g-C3N4 and CeO2 composite photocatalyst and provides a solution for the purification of pharmaceutical wastewater.

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
The environmental pollution by pharmaceutical wastewater has become one of the serious problems that cannot be ignored. As one kind of commonly used drugs, antibiotics, on the one hand, can save human lives [1], but on the other hand, they will make people develop resistance to drugs and thus produce superbugs that endanger the health of humans [2]. Therefore, it is necessary to develop purification treatment technology for pharmaceutical wastewater. As one of advanced oxidation processes (AOPs), photocatalysis is an excellent solar energy conversion technology and has been intensively researched and developed. Photocatalytic process makes use of light energy to produce active species (%O2−, %OH or h+) that has oxidation or reduction ability and can mineralize or reduce the target. In terms of water treatment, conventional membrane filtration technology and adsorption technology have limitations such as low efficiency, high cost, and time consuming [3]. In contrast, photocatalytic technology gradually and thoroughly decomposes pollutants through free radical reactions, demonstrating the advantages of green, efficiency and low cost.
Photocatalysis is such a green, environmentally friendly technology that it has been widely and successfully applied in various fields such as hydrogen evolution [4,5], degradation of drugs [6–8], oxidation of aromatic alcohols [9], mineralization of volatile organic compounds [10,11], reduction of aromatic nitro compounds [12,13], heavy metal ions reduction [14,15] and CO2 reduction [16,17], etc.
The synthesis of photocatalysts is the key to photocatalytic process. In recent years, photocatalysts with narrow band gaps that can absorb visible light have attracted the attention of researchers. Various metal oxides such as CeO2 (~2.8 eV) [18], MoO3 (~2.9 eV) [19], Bi2O3 (2.3–2.8 eV) [20], CuO (~1.2 eV) [21], Fe2O3 (~2.1 eV) [22] are the most popular used semiconductor materials for pollutant degradation and energy production. Recently, a metal-free organic polymeric semiconductor, graphitic carbon nitride (g-C3N4), has attracted tremendous attentions. g-C3N4 is composed of tri-s-triazine basic unit [23], and it can be easily obtained by thermal pyrolysis of low-cost nitrogenrich precursors such as urea [24], melamine [25], dicyandiamide [26], or thiourea [27]. g-C3N4 has a narrow band gap of about 2.7 eV [28], which can be driven under visible light, besides, it possesses high
https://doi.org/10.1016/j.seppur.2019.06.003 Received 25 April 2019; Received in revised form 29 May 2019; Accepted 2 June 2019
⁎ Corresponding author at: School of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering, Southwest Petroleum University, Chengdu 610500, China. E-mail address: jbzhou@swpu.edu.cn (J. Zhou).
Separation and Purification Technology 227 (2019) 115665
Available online 03 June 2019 1383-5866/ © 2019 Published by Elsevier B.V.
T
thermal stability, low toxicity [29]. Due to these advantages, g-C3N4 has been universally applied in the areas of photocatalytic organic pollutants and bacterial decomposition [30] and clean energy generation [31].
However, the photo-generated carriers’ recombination efficiency of g-C3N4 is high, resulting in unsatisfactory photocatalytic effect of it. In order to improve the photocatalytic activity of g-C3N4, it has been further studied to modify g-C3N4 with other semiconductors such as NiFe2O4 [32], Cu2O [33], BiOI [34], Bi2WO6 [35] and Ag2CO3 [36] or introduce metal [37] or non-metal [38] elements into it. These modifications can effectively enhance the photocatalytic activity of g-C3N4.
As a classic metal oxide semiconductor, CeO2 has been widely used in CO [39] and NOx [40] oxidation, CO2 reduction [41], hydrogen evolution [42], organics degradation [43] due to its characteristics of visible light absorption ability, narrow band gap and non-toxicity. However, pure CeO2 tends to have low photo-generated electrons-holes separation efficiency and low photocatalytic efficiency. In order to optimize its photocatalytic performance, element doping [44,45] and compound modification [46,47] are the common solution strategies. It also has been reported in some literatures [48–50] that the combination of g-C3N4 and CeO2 can improve their photocatalytic properties. Nevertheless, there has been few reports focus on the g-C3N4@CeO2 core-shell structure photocatalytic system.
Based on this, this work firstly established a composite catalyst system of g-C3N4@CeO2. Photocatalyst of g-C3N4 thin layer @ CeO2 sphere with a high specific surface area was synthesized by simple hydrothermal and in situ synthesis methods without using templates. The as-synthesized photocatalysts were combined with H2O2 for antibiotic doxycycline degradation in order to evaluate their degradation properties. And the as-prepared samples were also characterized by a series of techniques. This work studied the synthesis and photocatalytic properties of the core-shell structure of g-C3N4 and CeO2 system and provided a new idea for the synthesis of photocatalysts for pharmaceutical wastewater treatment.

sections.heading: 2.1. Materials and reagents
sections.text: Cerium nitrate hexahydrate (Ce(NO3)3·6H2O), urea, polyvinylpyrrolidone K-30 (PVP), 30% hydrogen peroxide (H2O2) and absolute ethanol were purchased from Sinopharm Chemical Reagent Co., Ltd. (Shanghai, China). Doxycycline hydrochloride (DOX) (purity≥ 98%) was purchased from Shanghai Macklin Biochemical Co., Ltd. (Shanghai, China).

sections.heading: 2.2.1. Preparation of g-C3N4
sections.text:
A 100mL ceramic crucible containing 20 g urea was placed in a
muffle furnace and calcined at 530 °C for 2 h [3,32]. After cooling to room temperature, the generated light yellow solid was crushed into light yellow powders, and g-C3N4 was obtained. By calcining 20 g of urea, 0.65 g of g-C3N4 can be obtained with the yield of 3.25%.

sections.heading: 2.2.2. Preparation of CeO2
sections.text: 4mmol Ce(NO3)3·6H2O was dissolved in 60mL deionized (DI) water. After it was completely dissolved, 0.4 g PVP was added to the above solution. After vigorously stirring for 2 h, the solution was transferred to a 100mL autoclave and reacted at 160 °C for 12 h. After cooling to room temperature, the brown precipitate at the bottom was collected and washed several times with DI water and absolute ethanol. It was then dried in an oven at 80 °C for 4 h. After that, the dried sample was placed in a muffle furnace and calcined at 400 °C for 2 h. Finally, the yellow CeO2 was obtained.

sections.heading: 2.2.3. Preparation of g-C3N4@CeO2
sections.text: 0.2 g as-prepared CeO2 was uniformly mixed with different masses of urea (0.1846, 0.3077, 0.4308 and 0.6154 g), then the mixture was placed in a ceramic crucible, and calcined at 530 °C for 2 h in the muffle furnace to obtain composites having different mass ratios of g-C3N4 to CeO2 (3%, 5%, 7% and 10%). The composites are abbreviated as 3% CN@CeO2, 5% CN@CeO2, 7% CN@CeO2 and 10% CN@CeO2, respectively. The schematic diagram of synthetic route is shown in Fig. 1.

sections.heading: 2.3. Characterization
sections.text:
The crystal phases of the as-prepared samples were analyzed by Xray diffractometer (XRD) (RU-200B/D/MAX-RB, Rigaku, Japan). The microstructures of the catalysts were examined by field emission scanning electron microscope (FESEM) (Zeiss Ultra Plus, Germany). Field emission high resolution transmission electron microscope (FHTEM) (JEM-2100F, Japan) was also used to test the morphologies of the samples. Fourier transform infrared (FTIR) spectra of the samples were acquired on a FTIR instrument (Nicolet 6700, USA) in the range of 400–4000 cm−1. UV–vis spectrophotometer (PerkinElmer Lambda 750 S, USA) was used to examine the optical absorption properties of the samples. The X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) (Thermo ESCALAB 250 Xi, USA) was used to analyze the elemental compositions. Fluorescence spectrophotometer (Gangdong F-380, China) was employed to acquire Photoluminescence (PL) spectra of the materials by using a 300W Xe arc lamp and excitation wavelength at 325 nm. The specific surface areas (BET) of the samples were measured by a particle analysis apparatus (TriStar II 3020, USA). The electron spin resonance (ESR) spectra were determined by using an ESR spectrometer (Bruker A
300, Germany).

sections.heading: 2.4. Photocatalytic performance test
sections.text: The evaluation of the photocatalytic activities of the as-synthesized materials was carried out by degrading the antibiotic doxycycline hydrochloride (DOX) under visible light irradiation. The visible light used was obtained by a 150W Xeon lamp with a 420 nm filter (CEL-HXF300, China). 50mg catalyst was added to 50mL DOX solution with the concentration of 0.01 g/L. The solution was stirred in the dark for 30min to achieve adsorption/desorption equilibrium, then 100 μL of 30% H2O2 was added in it. The solution was then irradiated under the visible light. 3 mL solution was taken every 10min and filtered through 0.22 μm filter film. The clarified solution was determined at 346 nm by an UV–visible spectrophotometer (Macy 1500, Shanghai, China).

sections.heading: 3.1. XRD results
sections.text: XRD was used to investigate the phase and composition of the asprepared materials. The XRD patterns of g-C3N4, CeO2, 3% CN@CeO2, 5% CN@CeO2, 7% CN@CeO2 and 10% CN@CeO2 are presented in Fig. 2. The characteristic diffraction peaks at 2 θ=13.1° and 27.3° are ascribed to the (1 1 1) plane (in-plane structure packing unit) and (0 0 2) plane (interlayer stacking) of g-C3N4 [51]. The peaks at 2 θ=28.44°, 33.0°, 47.52°, 56.38°, 59.16°, 69.38°, 76.8° and 79.02° of CeO2 sample are attributed to (1 1 1), (2 0 0), (2 2 0), (3 1 1), (2 2 2), (4 0 0), (3 3 1) and (4 2 0) planes of cubic fluorite structure of CeO2 crystals (JCPDS PDF#43-1002) [50]. No other impurity peaks are observed, indicating that the as-synthesized CeO2 has high purity. XRD patterns of all the composites exhibit the same diffraction peaks as CeO2, and no obvious characteristic peak of g-C3N4 was observed in them. That is because the content of g-C3N4 is very low in each composite. In addition, it can be observed that the peaks at 2 θ=28.44° of CeO2 slightly shifted to 28.54° over 10% CN@CeO2 sample, indicating that the combination of g-C3N4 has an effect on the lattice parameters of CeO2 [52], and g-C3N4 and CeO2 may form a close interaction. Further investigation of the interaction was performed by XPS.

sections.heading: 3.2. Morphology
sections.text:
SEM was used in order to study the microscopic morphologies of the as-synthesized materials. The results are shown in Fig. 3. Fig. 3a and b show the morphology of g-C3N4, which exhibits a curled lamellar structure. It can be clearly seen from Fig. 3c and d that the as-synthesized CeO2 exhibits a nano-sized spherical structure with a diameter of about 400–600 nm. The images of 5% CN@CeO2 are displayed in
Fig. 3e and f. It can be clearly observed from these images the thin layer of g-C3N4 is evenly wrapped on the surface of CeO2, forming the nanosized g-C3N4@CeO2 core-shell composite. In addition, the BET specific surface area, pore volume and pore size of CeO2, g-C3N4 and 5% CN@CeO2 composite are summarized in Table 1. As listed in Table 1, the specific surface areas of CeO2, g-C3N4 and 5% CN@CeO2 were determined to be 84.87m2/g, 38.68m2/g and 82.37m2/g respectively. CeO2 possesses higher specific surface area than g-C3N4 nanosheet due to its nano-sized spherical morphology. After in situ synthesis of the CN@CeO2 composite, the specific surface area, pore volume and pore size of 5% CN@CeO2 composite was not obviously changed compared to that of pure CeO2, which indicated that when the CeO2 was wrapped by the thin layer of g-C3N4, its specific surface area did not change significantly.
TEM was further employed to observe the detailed morphologies of g-C3N4, CeO2 and 5% CN@CeO2 composite. The results are shown in Fig. 4. Fig. 4a exhibits the graphite-like structure of g-C3N4, with extended laminar morphology. The structure images of different scales of the nano-sized CeO2 solid sphere are shown in Fig. 4b, c and d. The images of the composite are shown in Fig. 4e, f and g. Obviously, the outer layer of each CeO2 sphere is uniformly wrapped by the g-C3N4 nanosheets. Fig. 3h displays the HRTEM image of CeO2. The crystal lattices of 0.32 nm can be observed, which corresponds to the (1 1 1) plane of CeO2. SEM and TEM detection further illustrate the successful synthesis of the core-shell composite of g-C3N4@CeO2.

sections.heading: 3.3. FTIR analysis
sections.text: The FTIR spectra of as-prepared samples are presented in Fig. 5. For CeO2 sample, the peak located at 1627 cm−1 corresponds to the bending vibration of HeOeH bond [53,54]. In the fingerprint area below 1000 cm−1, the peak at 849 cm−1 represents the stretching vibration of CeeO bond [48,55]. For g-C3N4, the strong peak region between 3000 cm−1 and 3500 cm−1 corresponds to NeH bonds (amino groups) within g-C3N4 rings [56]. Peak at 1634 cm−1 is attributed to stretching vibration of C]N bond, and peaks from 1241 cm−1 to 1570 cm−1 are ascribed to stretching vibration of aromatic CeN bond [57] in addition, the peak at 810 cm−1 is related to out-of-plane bending vibration of triazine units [58,59]. Due to the low content, the FTIR peak of g-C3N4 is not significant in the composite, and all the composites display the characteristic peaks similar to CeO2. While, the peaks of vibration of Ce-O bonds of the composites shifted to lower wavenumber compared to pure CeO2, suggesting the formation of hydrogen bonds or conjugate effect between CeO2 and g-C3N4, and may reduce the density of the bonded electron cloud [49].

sections.heading: 3.4. UV–vis DRS analysis
sections.text:
The optical absorption properties of the as-synthesized materials were investigated by UV–vis DRS technology. The results are shown in Fig. 6. It can be seen from Fig. 6 that the absorption edge of g-C3N4 is at about 440 nm, and the as-synthesized pure CeO2 has the absorption edge of about 450 nm, and all the composites of g-C3N4@CeO2 show absorption edge very similar to CeO2. The absorption bands of these asprepared materials are all in the visible light region. The band gaps of the samples were calculated according to the following equation [60]:
= λEg 1240/ (1)
where λ is the maximum absorption wavelength of the sample. The band gaps (Eg) of g-C3N4 and CeO2 were calculated as 2.82 eV and 2.76 eV, respectively.

sections.heading: 3.5. XPS analysis
sections.text:
XPS characterization was used to study the surface element composition of the as-synthetic samples and the valence information of the
elements. The results are exhibited in Fig. 7. The C 1s spectra of g-C3N4 and 5% CN@CeO2 samples are shown in Fig. 7a. For g-C3N4, C 1s peak is divided to two peaks at 284.8 and 287.9 eV, and they are attributed to carbon impurity originated from the instrument and sp2 hybridized C-C bonds of graphitic carbon (NeC]N), respectively [61]. For the 5% CN@CeO2 sample, C 1s peak is divided to two peaks at 284.8 and 288.9 eV, the C 1s peak of 5% CN@CeO2 shifted toward higher binding energy due to the interactions between g-C3N4 and CeO2. As shown in Fig. 7b, N 1s peak of g-C3N4 is divided into three peaks at 398.3, 399.1
Table 1 Specific surface area and pore characteristics of as-prepared CeO2, g-C3N4 and 5% CN@CeO2 samples.
Sample BET surface area (m2 g−1)
Pore volume (cm3 g−1)
Pore size (nm)
CeO2 84.8691 0.052507 2.01815 g-C3N4 38.6762 0.134391 13.89915 5% CN@CeO2 82.3717 0.052426 1.94323
and 400.8 eV, and they belong to the sp2-hybridized nitrogen (C] NeC), tertiary nitrogen (Ne(C3)) groups and amino function groups, respectively [62,63]. The main N 1s peak of 5% CN@CeO2 sample shifts to 398.6 eV compared to the peak of g-C3N4 sample at 398.3 eV, indicating that there is strong interaction between g-C3N4 and CeO2 [50]. Fig. 7c presents the Ce 3d spectra of CeO2 and 5% CN@CeO2. It can be seen that the Ce element exists in a mixed valence state of Ce3+ and Ce4+. For both CeO2 and 5% CN@CeO2 samples, Ce 3d peaks were deconvoluted into eight peaks. Letters v and u represent Ce 3d5/2 and Ce 3d3/2 spin orbit of cerium ion, respectively. The peaks labelled as v, v″ and v‴ are assigned to Ce4+ 3d5/2 valence state, and v′ peak belong to Ce3+ 3d5/2 valence state. Peaks labelled as u, u″ and u‴ peaks are assigned to Ce4+ 3d3/2 valence state, and u' peak is assigned to Ce3+
3d3/2 valence state, respectively [64]. The peaks of Ce 3d of 5% CN@CeO2 sample located at 883.1, 886.3, 889.8, 898.9, 901.7, 904.3, 908.4 and 917.3 eV has slightly shifted 0.01–0.09 eV toward higher binding energy than CeO2 sample, suggesting that the chemical state of Ce in the composite is changed and a heterostructure has formed between g-C3N4 and CeO2 [65]. The O 1s spectra of CeO2 and 5% CN@CeO2 are displayed in Fig. 7d. The peaks at 529.3 and 531.3 eV are assigned to the lattice oxygen in CeO2 and oxygen species adsorbed on the surface, respectively [48].

sections.heading: 3.6. Visible-light catalytic activities
sections.text:
The photocatalytic activities of the as-synthesized samples were investigated by degrading DOX under visible light. The results are presented in Fig. 8. It can be observed from Fig. 8a that in the presence of only H2O2, almost no DOX was degraded in 60min. In the presence of only CeO2 or g-C3N4, the degradation efficiency was 14.8% or 18.3%, which was very poor. The 5% CN@CeO2 show insufficient degradation efficiency with 19.3% DOX was degraded. However, the photocatalytic efficiency of each sample was rapidly increased after the addition of 100 μL H2O2. The photocatalytic efficiencies of g-C3N4 and CeO2 reach to 66.7% and 71.7% in the presence of 100 μL H2O2. The photocatalytic efficiencies of 3% CN@CeO2, 5% CN@CeO2, 7% CN@CeO2, and 10% CN@CeO2 are 70.3%, 84%, 73.7% and 68.7%, respectively, which shows a trend of increase first and then decrease. 5% CN@CeO2 sample exhibits the best photocatalytic performance when combined with H2O2. That because the presence of a suitable amount of g-C3N4 minimizes the recombination of photogenerated carriers, also increases the efficiency of active species production during photocatalysis. When the content of g-C3N4 is small, photogenerated carriers’ recombination cannot be effectively suppressed. When the content of g-C3N4 is too much, it will cover the surface of CeO2, making it unable to effectively
use visible light energy. Moreover, it can be clearly seen that the addition of H2O2 can greatly increase the photocatalytic activity of the material in a short time, because H2O2 can react with the free radicals generated by the photocatalyst to generate more free radicals to oxidize the organic matter.
Moreover, the kinetics of photocatalytic degradation of DOX was investigated using the following equation:
− = kln(C/C ) t0 (2)
where, C0 is the concentration of DOX when photocatalysis starts, C is the concentration of DOX at time t and k is rate constant [66]. Fig. 8b displays the pseudo-first-order reaction kinetics curve for the photodegradation of DOX by as-prepared samples. The detailed rate constants
of the samples are shown in Fig. 8c. The rate constant for DOX degradation by 5% CN@CeO2+H2O2 (k=0.03275min−1) is the optimal one, which is 1.46 and 1.67 times higher than CeO2+H2O2 (k=0.02238min−1) and g-C3N4+H2O2 (k=0.01955min−1). And compared with pure CeO2 and pure g-C3N4, it is 11.65, 10.33 and 8.60 times much higher than pure CeO2 (k=0.00281min−1), pure g-C3N4 (k=0.00317min−1) and the composite of 5% CN@CeO2 (k=0.00381min−1).
Moreover, the effect of different addition volumes of H2O2 on photocatalytic efficiency is shown in Fig. 8d. The results showed that when the H2O2 volume increased from 50 μL to 100 μL, the photocatalytic efficiency was significantly improved, while H2O2 volume increased from 100 μL to 400 μL, the photocatalytic efficiency increased slightly. Thus, 100 μL H2O2 was chosen to add in the DOX solution to assist photodegradation. The degradation results indicated that DOX could be successfully degraded by using the as-synthesized catalyst combined with H2O2.
In order to further investigate the stability and reusability of the composite photocatalyst, four successive DOX degradation experiments by using 5% CN@CeO2 photocatalyst coupled with H2O2 were performed under visible light. The same photocatalyst was washed by DI water and dried by oven after each degradation test, and then used again for the next cycling run under the same conditions. The relevant results are shown in Fig. 9. As displayed in Fig. 9, after four cycles of degradation, 5% CN@CeO2 still maintained high photocatalytic activity with 82.1% DOX decomposition ratio, implying that the composite photocatalyst has good stability durability, and can be used repeatedly.

sections.heading: 3.7. PL analysis
sections.text:
The recombination efficiency of photogenerated carriers is the key factor affecting the photocatalytic degradation results. Therefore, in
order to study the photogenerated electron-hole recombination of the as-synthesized material, PL detection was performed. And the results are displayed in Fig. 10. It can be seen that all CeO2 and CN@CeO2 composites exhibit PL peaks at 430 nm and 470 nm under excitation wavelength at 325 nm. Pure CeO2 exhibits the strongest peak intensity, indicating that photogenerated electron hole pairs have high recombination efficiency. The peak intensities of all the composites are lower than that of CeO2, indicating that the composite of g-C3N4 on the surface of CeO2 can effectively inhibit the recombination of photogenerated carriers. 5% CN@CeO2 shows the lowest peak intensity, indicating that it has the lowest photogenerated electron-hole recombination efficiency. Which explains that 5% CN@CeO2 has the best degradation efficiency.

sections.heading: 3.8. Active species trapping experiments
sections.text:
As well known, during the photocatalytic degradation process, the photocatalyst generates photo-generated electron-hole pairs by utilizing light energy. Photo-generated electrons and holes thereby form various active species such as (%O2−) and hydroxyl radical (%OH) [67], and these active species can cause decomposition of the pollutants [68]. In order to find out the roles of the active species during photodegradation process, active species trapping experiments were carried out by using 5% CN@CeO2 sample. Nitrogen (N2), ethylenediamine tetraacetic acid disodium salt (EDTA-2Na) and isopropanol (IPA) were used as superoxide radical (%O2−), holes (h+) and hydroxyl radical (%OH) scavengers, respectively [50,69]. The results of active species trapping experiments are shown in Fig. 11. Fig. 11a shows the results of active species trapping experiments in the absence of H2O2. It can be clearly seen that when no scavenger was added, the DOX degradation rate of 5% CN@CeO2 reached 91.9% at 160min. When N2, EDTA-2Na and IPA were added, the degradation rates reduced to 13.5%, 24.3% and 59.3%, respectively. The results indicated that %O2− played major role, h+ played the second important role, while %OH was not the main reactive species during the photocatalytic process in the absence of H2O2. Active species trapping experiments were also performed in the presence of H2O2. The results are shown in Fig. 11b. The results revealed that when no scavenger was added, the DOX degradation rate of 5% CN@CeO2 was 84% at 60min. DOX degradation efficiency reduced to 15.8%, 25.5% and 31.4% respectively when N2, EDTA-2Na and IPA were added. The results suggested that in the presence of H2O2, %O2− still played dominant role, while %OH also become an important active species, because the addition of H2O2, more %OH were formed in the system to participate in the oxidation of DOX.
To further verify the presence of the free radicals, ESR tests were performed on the 5% CN@CeO2 sample, and the results are shown in Fig. 12. As presented in Fig. 12a, the ESR strong signal exhibits typical six peaks, which is attributed to %O2−. It can be seen that as the
illumination time increased, the peak intensity of %O2− gradually increased. In Fig. 12b, four typical peaks attributed to %OH are obviously observed. The peak strength of %O2− is stronger than %OH, indicating that the number of %O2− produced is greater than that of %OH. From Fig. 12, it is clear that the CN@CeO2 photocatalyst system can generated both %O2− and %OH by capturing visible light.

sections.heading: 3.9. Possible degradation mechanism
sections.text:
In order to study the mechanism of photocatalytic degradation of DOX over 5% CN@CeO2 system, the positions of the respective conduction band (CB) and valence band (VB) of g-C3N4 and CeO2 need to be calculated. The VB of g-C3N4 and CeO2 were measured as 1.80 eV and 2.06 eV through the VB-XPS tests which is shown in Fig. 13, and the results are consistent with the literature reports [50,70].
According to the following formula:
= −E E ECB VB g (3)
the values of the CB of g-C3N4 and CeO2 were calculated to be−0.70 eV and −1.02 eV, respectively. Both g-C3N4 and CeO2 can generate photogenerated e− and h+ when excited by visible light. The CB potentials of them are negative than O2/%O2− (−0.13 eV vs. NHE, at pH=7) [71], therefore, both of g-C3N4 and CeO2 can generate %O2−. The VB potential of CeO2 is greater than OH−/%OH (+1.99 eV vs. NHE, at pH=7) [54], so %OH can be produced by it, while g-C3N4 cannot produce %OH. Combining the results of ESR and PL tests, a possible mechanism is proposed and shown in Fig. 14. After being irradiated by visible light, photogenerated e− on CB of g-C3N4 are transferred to the CB of CeO2, and the accumulated e− convert O2 into %O2−, therefore, the ESR signal intensity of the %O2− is gradually enhanced. At the same time, the h+ on VB of CeO2 are partially transferred to the VB of g-
C3N4, resulting in a slight decrease in the ESR signal intensity of the %OH. The transfer of e− and h+ between g-C3N4 and CeO2 can suppress the photo-generated carriers’ recombination efficiency, so that the PL peak intensity of 5% CN@CeO2 is lower than pure g-C3N4 and CeO2. Then %O2− and %e− react with H2O2 in water to form more %OH to degrade DOX. The specific reaction steps are summarized as follows:
g-C3N4@CeO2+ hv→ g-C3N4 (e−+h+)@CeO2 (e−+h+) (4)
g-C3N4 (e−+h+)@CeO2 (e−+h+)→ g-C3N4 (h++h+)@CeO2 (e−+e−) (5)
e−+O2→ %O2− (6)
e−+H2O2→ %OH+OH− (7)
%O2−+H2O2→ %OH+ %OH+O2 (8)
h++H2O→ %OH+H+ (9)
%O2−+h++ %OH+DOX→ Products+CO2+H2O (10)

sections.heading: 4. Conclusions
sections.text:
In this work, g-C3N4@CeO2 core-shell photocatalyst was firstly synthesized by a simple in-situ synthesis method, and it was combined with H2O2 to successfully degrade DOX. Due to the high specific surface area and low photogenerated carriers recombination efficiency, 5% CN@ CeO2 has the highest degradation efficiency when combined with 100 μL H2O2. The rate constant for DOX degradation by 5% CN@CeO2+H2O2 (k=0.03275min−1) is 1.46 and 1.67 times higher than CeO2+H2O2 (k=0.02238min−1) and g-C3N4+H2O2 (k=0.01955min−1). And is 11.65 and 10.33 times much higher than pure CeO2 (k=0.00281min−1), pure g-C3N4 (k=0.00317min−1).
After being excited by visible light, the active radicals can combine with H2O2 to generate more hydroxyl radicals for oxidation reaction, thereby accelerating the degradation rate of DOX. This study provides a new and effective degradation system for photocatalytic treatment of pharmaceutical wastewater.

Photocatalysis is such a green, environmentally friendly technology that it has been widely and successfully applied in various fields such as hydrogen evolution [4,5], degradation of drugs [6–8], oxidation of aromatic alcohols [9], mineralization of volatile organic compounds [10,11], reduction of aromatic nitro compounds [12,13], heavy metal ions reduction [14,15] and CO2 reduction [16,17], etc.

Due to these advantages, g-C3N4 has been universally applied in the areas of photocatalytic organic pollutants and bacterial decomposition [30] and clean energy generation [31].
Due to these advantages, g-C3N4 has been universally applied in the areas of photocatalytic organic pollutants and bacterial decomposition [30] and clean energy generation [31].

In order to improve the photocatalytic activity of g-C3N4, it has been further studied to modify g-C3N4 with other semiconductors such as NiFe2O4 [32], Cu2O [33], BiOI [34], Bi2WO6 [35] and Ag2CO3 [36] or introduce metal [37] or non-metal [38] elements into it.

As a classic metal oxide semiconductor, CeO2 has been widely used in CO [39] and NOx [40] oxidation, CO2 reduction [41], hydrogen evolution [42], organics degradation [43] due to its characteristics of visible light absorption ability, narrow band gap and non-toxicity.

metadata.abstractText: In this work, g-C3N4 thin layer @ CeO2 core-shell composite photocatalyst was synthesized by simple hydrothermal and in situ synthesis method for the first time, and it was combined with hydrogen peroxide (H2O2) to degrade the antibiotic doxycycline hydrochloride (DOX) under visible light. A series of techniques were employed to characterize the as-synthesized materials. XRD patterns indicated that the samples were successfully synthesized. SEM and TEM images displayed the core-shell microstructure of the as-synthesized composite. The surface element composition and the valence states of the samples were characterized by XPS. The optical properties of the materials were determined by DRS and FTIR. The results of FTIR and XPS indicated that strong interactions between g-C3N4 and CeO2 had formed during the synthesis process. Photodegradation experiments showed that the addition of H2O2 can greatly enhance the photocatalytic degradation rate of DOX. Active species trapping experiments and ESR experiments demonstrated that superoxide radicals, hydroxyl radicals and holes (O2, OH and h) played major roles in the photocatalytic process. Finally, a possible degradation mechanism was proposed. This work has synthesized a new core-shell structure system for g-C3N4 and CeO2 composite photocatalyst and provides a solution for the purification of pharmaceutical wastewater.
metadata.creator: Elsevier
